document:
Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of  Fianna Fáil hope to avoid a second election.
Mr Martin has said his party will facilitate a minority government, but will not support a programme for government.
Water charges are one of the main sticking points to reaching agreement.
A commission to consider the future of national water utility Irish Water is one of the proposals being considered.
Fianna Fáil want to see the immediate removal of water charges, but Fine Gael see a role for them.
Following the election, almost two months ago, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23 and the Labour Party got seven.
But no party was able to form a majority government and TDs have so far failed to elect a taoiseach.
claim: the republic of ireland\'s two main political parties are to vote on whether to take control of water charges.
doc_sents: Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of  Fianna Fáil
hope to avoid a second election.
Mr Martin has said his party will facilitate a minority government, but will not support a programme for government.
Water charges are one of the main sticking points to reaching agreement.
A commission to consider the future of national water utility Irish Water is one of the proposals being considered.
Fianna Fáil want to see the immediate removal of water charges, but Fine Gael see a role for them.
Following the election, almost two months ago, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23 and the Labour Party got seven.
But no party was able to form a majority government and TDs have so far failed to elect a taoiseach.
sum_sents: the republic of ireland\'s two main political parties are to vote on whether to take control of water charges.

1. The summary statements are all supported by the article.
Therefore, the answer is yes, the summary is consistent with the article.
human_reason:
1. The summary states that the two main political parties in the Republic of Ireland are to vote on whether to take control of water charges. 2. However, the article states that water charges are one of the main sticking points to reaching agreement. In the article, there is no mention of voting to take control of water charges. Instead, the two parties are negotiating to reach an agreement.
Therefore, the answer is no, the summary is not consistent with the article.

Step 1: Identify the main topic of the article.
The article is about the two main political parties in Ireland, Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil, trying to avoid a second election and their stance on water charges.

Step 2: Compare the main topic with the summary.
The summary states that the two main political parties are to vote on whether to take control of water charges.

Step 3: Analyze the consistency of the summary with the article.
The article mentions that water charges are one of the main sticking points to reaching an agreement between the two parties. It also states that Fianna Fáil wants to see the immediate removal of water charges, while Fine Gael sees a role for them. However, the summary does not mention the parties' positions on water charges and only states that they are to vote on whether to take control of water charges.

Step 4: Answer the question.
No, the summary is not consistent with the corresponding article, as it does not mention the parties' positions on water charges and only states that they are to vote on whether to take control of water charges.
